item.text: The recent "catcalling" video is a good demonstration of why research methods matter for everyone, not just scientists. Increasingly the public is presented with data that has the appearance and tone of science, but lacks the rigor. The catcalling video is one such example.

The recent "catcalling" video is a good demonstration of why research methods matter for everyone, not just scientists. Increasingly the public is presented with data that has the appearance and tone of science, but lacks the rigor. The catcalling video is one such example.
item.title: Catcall Research Methods

item.text:
YOUTUBE b1XGPvbWn0A
(double-click to edit caption)

The recent "catcalling" video is a good demonstration of why research methods matter for everyone, not just scientists. Increasingly the public is presented with data that has the appearance and tone of science, but lacks the rigor.  This can lead to misunderstandings of data means.
This is not to denigrate the video, which in capturing the actions of catcalling men righly evokes disgust in the viewer and awareness of the problem.
The issue is the treatment of such a video as a scientific artifact.

The issue is the treatment of such a video as a scientific artifact. As Zeynep Tufekci notes on Medium, the presentation of quantitative data in the film encourages viewers to see the experience captured in the film as broadly significant, ultimately leading to (unsubstantiated) racist conclusions.
Science takes care and planning.

The issue is the treatment of such a video as a scientific artifact. As Zeynep Tufekci notes on Medium, the presentation of quantitative data in the film encourages viewers to see the experience captured in the film as broadly significant, ultimately leading to (unsubstantiated) racist conclusions.

The issue is the treatment of such a video as a scientific artifact. As Zeynep Tufekci notes on Medium, the presentation of quantitative data in the film encourages viewers to see the experience captured in the film as broadly significant, ultimately leading to (unsubstantiated) racist conclusions. While racist interpretations belong to those that propagate them, the video's absence of method leaves the door open to them.

The issue is the treatment of such a video as a scientific artifact. As Zeynep Tufekci notes on Medium, the presentation of quantitative data in the film encourages viewers to see the experience captured in the film as broadly significant, ultimately leading to (unsubstantiated) racist conclusions. While racist interpretations belong to those that propagate them, the video's absence of method leaves the door open to them. [https://medium.com/message/that-catcalling-video-and-why-research-methods-is-such-an-exciting-topic-really-32223ac9c9e8 html]

The issue is the treatment of such a video as a scientific artifact. As Zeynep Tufekci notes on Medium, the presentation of quantitative data in the film encourages viewers to see the experience captured in the film as broadly significant, ultimately leading to (unsubstantiated) racist conclusions. And while racist interpretations belong to those that propagate them, the video's absence of method leaves the door open to them. [https://medium.com/message/that-catcalling-video-and-why-research-methods-is-such-an-exciting-topic-really-32223ac9c9e8 html]
Science takes care and planning, and understanding data requires nuance.
Science takes care and planning, and understanding data requires nuance. As we move into an era of YouTube science, we should keep both these concerns front of mind.

The recent "catcalling" video is a good demonstration of why research methods matter for everyone, not just scientists. Increasingly the public is presented with data that has the appearance and tone of science, but lacks the rigor.  This can lead to misunderstandings of what data means.
This is not to denigrate the video, which in capturing the actions of catcalling men rightly evokes disgust in the viewer and awareness of the problem.

Science takes care and planning, and understanding data requires nuance and access to detailed descriptions of methodology. As we move into an era of YouTube science, we should keep both these concerns front of mind.

Science takes care and planning, and understanding data requires nuance and access to detailed descriptions of methodology. As we move into an era of YouTube science, we should keep both these concerns front of mind. Demand methodology and data as a viewer, and provide it as a producer.

The recent "catcalling" video is a good demonstration of why research methods matter for everyone, not just scientists. Increasingly the public is presented with data that has the appearance and tone of science, but lacks the rigor.  This can lead to misunderstandings of what data means. (See Zeynep Tufekci's post:[https://medium.com/message/that-catcalling-video-and-why-research-methods-is-such-an-exciting-topic-really-32223ac9c9e8 html])

The issue is the treatment of such a video as a scientific artifact. As Zeynep Tufekci notes on Medium, the presentation of quantitative data in the film encourages viewers to see the experience captured in the film as broadly significant, ultimately leading to (unsubstantiated) racist conclusions. And while racist interpretations belong to those that propagate them, the video's absence of a documented methodology leaves the door open to them. story.text: The recent "catcalling" video is a good demonstration of why research methods matter for everyone, not just scientists. Increasingly the public is presented with data that has the appearance and tone of science, but lacks the rigor.  This can lead to misunderstandings of what data means. (See Zeynep Tufekci's post:[https://medium.com/message/that-catcalling-video-and-why-research-methods-is-such-an-exciting-topic-really-32223ac9c9e8 html])
This is not to denigrate the video, which in capturing the actions of catcalling men rightly evokes disgust in the viewer and awareness of the problem.

The issue is the treatment of such a video as a scientific artifact. As Zeynep Tufekci notes on Medium, the presentation of quantitative data in the film encourages viewers to see the experience captured in the film as broadly significant, ultimately leading to (unsubstantiated) racist conclusions. And while racist interpretations belong to those that propagate them, the video's absence of a documented methodology leaves the door open to them. [https://medium.com/message/that-catcalling-video-and-why-research-methods-is-such-an-exciting-topic-really-32223ac9c9e8 html]

Science takes care and planning, and understanding data requires nuance and access to detailed descriptions of methodology. As we move into an era of YouTube science, we should keep both these concerns front of mind. Demand methodology and data as a viewer, and provide it as a producer.
